stagger.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to walk or move unsteadily, almost falling over
stagger.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The old man staggered drunkenly to his feet.
stagger.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make someone feel very surprised or shocked
stagger.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: What staggered us was the sheer size of her salary.
stagger.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to continue doing something when you seem to be going to fail and you do not know what will happen
stagger.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: He staggered on for another two years.
The company staggered from one crisis to the next.
stagger.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to arrange people’s working hours, holidays etc so that they do not all begin and end at the same time
stagger.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Jim and his wife stagger their work hours so one of them can be at home with the kids.
stagger.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to start a race with each runner at a different place on a curved track
stagger.translation[1].definitions[0].de: an unsteady movement of someone who is having difficulty in walking
stagger.translation[2].definitions[0].de: to arrange people’s working hours, holidays etc so that they do not all begin and end at the same time
stagger.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The meetings are staggered throughout the day to give shift workers the opportunity to attend.
More could be done to encourage staggered working hours.
stagger.translation[2].definitions[1].de: to arrange a series of payments, deliveries etc so that they do not all happen at the same time
stagger.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The loan repayments were staggered over a long period.
The remaining aircraft will be delivered on a staggered basis by the year 2025.
